Because, in case you hadn't noticed, this article is about Sally Ride and how events were related to her.  It just happens not to be primarily about the Challenger investigation, nor many other interesting topics.  Glad I could clear that up for you.

Seattle expat: By all accounts I've read, Ride had little or nothing to do with finding the problem or confronting NASA over its wrong-headed push to launch the Challenger. James Gleick's research indicated it was Feynman mainly who accomplished this, and that Ride was among those who didn't stand up for Feynman when he sought to have his conclusion published in the main body of the commission report (it became, in Feynman's words, the "inflamed appendix" afterward to the full report only because Feynman refused to let it drop).

I have nothing against Ride - a lot of respect for her, actually - but this article by the Times leaves an impression that Ride was courageous in confronting NASA and instrumental in getting the truth out. She did no such thing, at least that I've ever read about. Yes, the article is about Ride, is in fact her obituary, but it needs to be correct in detail and in overall impression made, and insofar as the Challenger commission is concerned, I'm afraid the article falls short.

By the time the investigation began, many people were aware that the o-rings probably caused the problem. Neither Feynman nor Ride "discovered" this. They helped clarify it; they explained it to the public; they helped cut through the nonsense and evasions; and they helped make sure this was emphasized in the final report. In his memoirs Feynman gave credit to Ride and the other members of the panel.

"One witness was Roger Boisjoly, an engineer who had worked for the company that made the shuttle’s rocket boosters and who had been shunned by colleagues for revealing that he had warned his bosses and NASA that the boosters’ seals, called O-rings, could fail in cold weather. The Challenger had taken off on a cold morning.
After his testimony, Dr. Ride, who was known to be reserved and reticent, publicly hugged him. She was the only panelist to offer him support. Mr. Boisjoly, who died in February, said her gesture had helped sustain him during a troubled time."

I think that is was the late Richard Feyman that showed the O rings were faulty supporting Mr. Boisjoly concerns. If I remember it was Rider and Feyman who pulled the plug. Why is Feyman npt mentioned?

To further zero in on the point being made by David Brooks and Diana Moses, I recommend a close study of the psychiatric theory and practice of Erik Erikson as outlined and popularized in, for instance, "Identity and the Life Cycle."

It is not the availability of mental health that is the problem so much as trying to get an afflicted person to accept that help or even to seek it out. More often than not, family and friends of mentally ill people recognize the problem and try to get the mentally ill loved one to get help and are fought tooth and nail by them.
The law is no help in this regard and only serves to strengthen the feeling of impotence in dealing with an afflicted loved one. According to the law of the land (as far as I am aware) unless the person is a danger to themselves or others nobody can step in to force treatment on them. If James Holmes had been diagnosed with a mental illness and refused treatment there is nothing anyone could do until a tragic event occurred. He was perfectly within his rights to remain crazy as long he caused no harm. And in truth, most of the time this is not an issue.
I don' t know what the answer to this quandary is. I wish I did. But speaking from experience, until something is done to address the issue of being able to force treatment on someone, or at least to be able to have them committed for observation against their will to determine if they are a threat to the safety of themselves, families, friends, and the public at large- these anomalies will continue to threaten us.

If we want a society that's dynamic because there are winners and losers (which I believe is necessary for people to take the risks to develop innovative solutions and take advantage of extraordinary gifts), we also have to have a way for the losers in that equation to feel okay about themselves.  While celebrating the winners, the losers can be satisfied with doing their best; contributing in some other way (great relationships and family, etc.).  And the winners don't need to be treated with such deference and can themselves be more in touch with reality in understanding that they're in most ways just like everyone else - not that special.

I think if the general culture paid more constructive attention both to things like known stages of development when mental illness may manifest itself and to how to weather life's blows, some individuals might end up wandering less damaging paths in their lives.  We did start to talk about STDs publicly at some point, for example, why not about mental health issues that arise during adolescence and young adulthood?  We could put them on more people's radar, make it more acceptable to seek help (and yes, I realize that the help is not always easy to be found).  And we could do more to help people be ready for weathering life's blows, instead of just expecting everybody to wing it successfully.  While these kinds of strategies would not reach people deep in the throes of mental illness, they might (through earlier detection and intervention, development of better coping skills, and more cultural support for asking for help) help keep some people from struggling so much or from getting to the point at which it is difficult for others to reach them.

There is NOTHING fair about capitalism. Pure capitalism is ONLY about opportunity, it makes NO promises of reward to anyone. Further, historical evidence is pretty convincing that pure unmanaged capitalism almost inevitably corrupts government and generates an oligopoly, i.e. a class of wealthy which itself acts  corruptly to maintain itself. The rise of the middle class through the middle of the 20th century was primarily due to two things - first, the New Deal and creation of social safety nets and government funded higher education, and second, the availability of relatively inexpensive locally produced oil. With US Peak Oil hitting in the early 1970s, there was no way to keep growth going at the same rate. As a result, the Republican party initiated an insidious form of class warfare against the middle class, but using clever advertising to convince much of the middle class that it was doing the opposite (which it was not). It is not necessary here to repeat the obvious, that high marginal tax rates in the 1950s-70s were never a barrier to growth or to overall social welfare. With the end of peak oil, the wealthy saw their future profits failing and acted accordingly. The problem is the failure of the middle class voter to see this obvious trend, so that it repeatedly voted republican leaders into place. By now actually both parties are at least somewhat corrupt, but at least one party tries to mitigate against this, whereas the other has totally embraced it.

How does globalization explain the trends we observe?

First of all it depresses the relative wages of unskilled and less-skilled labor, as it introduces competition for these jobs from workers in less developed economies. Businesses have increasingly made use of the overseas labor to reduce costs and therefore increase profits. Some of these lower costs have been passed along to consumers, decreasing the cost of living.

Secondly, it increases the payoff to winning in business. The market for a successful product or service becomes the world instead of a neighborhood, state or country. Corporations have grown in size, selling products and services worldwide. The monetary rewards accruing to those providing the goods and services have grown together with their size and global reach. Entrepreneurs, CEOs, entertainers, star athletes and others at the top have become fabulously wealthy. Because their supply is relatively limited, the compensation for knowledge workers has also grown faster than GDP.

Some would suggest that globalization should be resisted rather than embraced. I think such an action would be self-defeating in the long run. The trend towards global integration is inevitable, and, by fighting it, a country merely guarantees that it will be left behind.

Finally, globalization materially helps developing countries and their most vulnerable citizens, as can be seen from the quickly dropping global poverty rate.

The question is what caused the median income in the U.S. to fall and the income concentration to rise in the near term. First of all, an objective eye indicates that a slower growth trend in median family income started around 1968, not at the start of Reagan's or Bush II's term. The peak of median income in 2000 was likely a fluke caused by the tech bubble and not something to make too much of. The recent decline is due to the worst recession since the Great Depression, and is not so meaningful as an endpoint, either. So this is more about what happened around 1968.

I cannot easily find a chart going back before 1960, but from this chart, http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:USexportsgs1960-2004.gif , it is pretty clear that one thing that happened was a rapid acceleration of international trade. I prefer globalization as the main cause of the trend, and I think it explains the main characteristics of the current situation.

There are two other main narratives presented to explain the same data. One is that greedy financiers at the top stole wealth from the middle class through greed and nefarious means, enabled by lax regulations. The other is that through cooption of the government, rich oligarchs protected their positions at the top, and used government connections to enrich themselves. Both of these explanations are much to involved and complicated in my opinion, no matter how satisfying they may be to those who believe them.
